info.title: Rediscover DevOps configuration
info.description:
This document describes the specification of the 
proposed file **.well-known/devops.json** that can 
be used in the DevOps CI/CD as identifier for
information required by the tools.

By using the .well-known location, assumptions are
reduced if not eliminated by the automation tools.

The end result is a design using HATEOS principles where further
information on a resource can be obatined by following the bread crumbs of the 
relationships in the **.well-known/devops.json** file.

Automation tools can also validate the information during 
source commit to confirm the engineers are providing the necessary 
information and that it is valid.

The **devops.json** file has been defined using OpenAPI but that does not imply that
a real API needs to be deployed or used.  On the contrary it is unlikely that the main
copy stored on Git is accessed via a API service.  

You could build a catalogue service of all your **devops.json** definitions linked to
Git definitions, but that is not a specification requirement.

For further information see https://github.com/meerkat-manor/rediOps

/devops/.description:
This service will list the **devops** definitions registered 
with it.

This definition is only applicable if the **deveops** is
published as a service outside of the source code.

404.description: No match for resource or no resources exist

get.description:
Capability to list matching resorces captured from
code repositories

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: List resources with matching asset id

/devops/{id}.description:
This service and its operations are intended for use where 
the DevOps information from source versioning (e.g. Git)
is wanted to be stored on a centrral registry.

The process of updating the central registry can be automated by use
of web hooks which will retrieve the latest **.well-known/deveops.json**
from Git on commits as an example.

This definition is only applicable if the **deveops** is
published as a service outside of the source code.

404.description: The required Devops recor with the requested identity wasnot found.

get.description:
For web servers that provide a DevOps catalogue,this service
fetches the details for the requested DevOps identity

200.description:
The updated record is returned to the caller
on succssful update

post.description:
This service is for servers providing a catalogue service
for DevOps information.  The original Git details are not required to
be updated.

You could create a capability where this POST is used to 
update the source details and commit those changes.

/health.summary: Fetch the health of the service
/health.description:
The service will return either a 200 (OK) or a 503 error message

This definition is only applicable if the **deveops** is
published as a service outside of the source code.

/.well-known/devops.json.description:
This fetches the **devops.json" file for this service,

This definition is only applicable if the **deveops** is
published as a service outside of the source code.

get.description:
Commonly the DevOps information is not fetched using a REST API but is actually the JSON file stored the root **.well-known** directory as the file name **devops.json**

If so required there can be a supporting REST API to fetch the contents, but that is not the primary intent.

owner-contact.title: Root Type for asset-owner
owner-contact.description:
The name and /or contact detals of the DevOps owner.

The owner can be a single person or a team.  It is preferale thati t is more
granualr then the organisation.

If you have a CMDB catalgue then the entry here should match the details on
the CMDB if you choose to include them here.

The contact details do not include a phone / mobile / cell number on purpose
as this information is either know by the reader for the person / team or
can be obtained from an organisations internal directory.

Automated tools are unlikely to benefit from having access to a phone number, but they
can send emails or post messages to Slack.

email.description:
The email adress of the owner.

The email address could be a distribution list.

web.description:
A web page URL for the owner.

The web page could refer to a team page.

matrix.description: The matrrix IM identfier of the owner

name.description:
The name of the owner.

This may be persons or teams name.

engine.description:
Engine used for activties.

For example the engine name can be:

* azure-pipeline
* circle-ci
* jenkins

config.description: A configuration file that can be an URL location or a Git folder

script.description:
A script file that is executed to perform the activity.

The choice of processing engine is up to the organisation, or 
some assumptions can be made based on file extension.

For example:

* .sh = Bash
* .ps1 = PowerShell
* .bat = MS DOS command

dependency-model.title: Root Type for dependency-action
dependency-model.description:
The dependency section provides information on:

1. APIs that the service calls such as ODBC, Authentication, System of Record API
2. Tools that are required for build, testing and deployment

apis.description:
List of downstream dependency APIs.

The list can include:

1. RESTful APIs
2. SOAP APIs
3. File transfer APIs
4. ODBC or JDBC connections

No credentials are required to be captured in the definiton. Please do not include user names or passwords.

repository-model.title: Root Type for repository
repository-model.description:
Link information to repositories for various registeries.

You can add custom extensions with prefix **x-**

guide.description: Link to documentation on repositories used by this component

artefact.description:
Artefact engine

Some common engines are:

* Artifactory
* Archiva

CI servers can also have their own repository for generated artifact

source.description:
Source version control system engine.

This can be used by tools to retreive source code using binary executables.

Some common tools are "Git", "TFS", "Mercurial", "CVS".

tools-model.title: Root Type for tools-action
tools-model.description:
The purpose of the tools section is an aid to identify the various tols required 
during build, testing and deployment.  This can server as a documentation item 
or actually preparing the nevironment to contain the necessary tool.

If you are using a well defined tool that is linked to your source versioning by
web hook then you are not likely to require this section for execution. 

A sample use case for a simple environment is to identify a tool that needs
to be fetched from an artifact storage location as it is required by the 
deployment install script.

guide.description: Link to documentation for the tool in the context of this DevOps

engine.description:
The processor to execute the commands.

For example you can define it as "powershell" to execute script file with extension .ps1

You cannot combine different commands for different processors in the one tools set.  If you have different
processors you can define multiple tools.

asset-model.title: Root Type for asset-id
asset-model.description:
A reference record linking the resource to an organisation asset record
such as a CMDB entry.

id.description: An external identifier for this rsource.

name.description:
A name of the resource in the asset (CMDB) registry.

This could differ from the name specified in the 
parent level.

url.description: An URL to the resource in the asset (CMDB) registry.

deploy-model.title: Root Type for devops-action
deploy-model.description:
Provides information of the commands or scripts to use when
the resources is bing installed, refreshed or uninstalled.

The script or playbook can be sourced from the source version manager (e.g. Git)

guide.description: Link to documentation for the topic

engine.description: The processor to understand and execute the commands or playbook.

commands.description: Commands or script to be processed

health-model.title: Root Type for health-model
health-model.description:
Lists the health services the resource exposes.

The guide can provide more detais about the health checks and their depth of checking.

guide.description: Link to documentation describing the health check

api.description:
List of health check APIs published by the
resource

healthapi-model.title: Root Type for healthapi-modle
healthapi-model.description:
Describes the health service that the resource exposes.

The definition can inlcude expected response details

url.description:
URL for health check path.  The path if suppied must
match a path in the service definition (OpenAPI)

Using the URL path the details of the health check can
be found in the service definition.

Normally a human coud make an intelligent assumption on
what the name of the health check but a machine will find it
more difficult.  Also consider how you would identify it 
in a foreign language.

status.description: The HTTP status code for a successful health check.

response.description: The expected response body from a healthy service

commands-model.title: Root Type for commands
commands-model.description: Commands are executed by the engine.  The commands need to be constructed in a format compatible with the engine.

pre.description: Commands if any that are executed before the script and post items.

script.description:
A single script thais executed after the "pre" and before the "post" commands.
The script can be an URL or a file within the version control (e.g. Git) repository.

post.description: Commands if any that are executed after the script.

engine-model.title: Root Type for engine-model
engine-model.description: Engine details as used for apis, build, testing, configuration and deployment

name.description:
A common name for the tool, such as:

* makefile
* teamcity
* azure-pipeline

The choice is up to you but you should keep it consistent.

url.description:
Link to engine or its configuration

The format of the URL will depend on the engine

api-model.title: Root Type for api
api-model.description:
A link to the API definition in OpenAPI format.

The definition file can be source from various locations, with
the most commo being either Git or REST (HTTPS) accessible 
locations.

A Git file can be accessed with Git command while REST / HTTPS
might use the "wget" or "curl" commands

guide.description: Link to documentation for the topic

engine.description:
The engine that the Url refers to.  As the Url format is used by various 
processors, an engine value is required for proper processing.

The acceptable values will depend on the organisation, but the
minimal values that need to be supported are:

* GIT for Git located resources.  For this case the Git resource is assumed 
  to be in the Git repository for this DevOps resource if the prefix is not
  HTTPS
* REST for HTTP/S based web pages that are no explicitly handled by other engines

Other possible values might be:

* FILE for local or LAN based resources 
* S/FTP for FTP based URL resources

url.description:
A full URL for the API or if the value is partial
then the location is assumed to be on the Git repo.  That is the host name and
Git name are the same as for the "devops.json" file.

If the resource details are being supplied by a catalogu service
then the value in the "repository" section will be used.

health-response.title: Root Type for health-response
health-response.description:
A response to the **/health** service
and not a data model for **rediops** model
as used in the **devops.json** definition

unique_id.description:
Unique identifier 

This is only applicable when the definition is serviced from a catalogue
that requires unique identifers.

Do not use the Git repository URL as the unique identifier because
to retrieve the file you would have to know the location.

version.description:
Specification version

Major versions may not be compatible with minor versions.

created_on.description:
Date and time this content was first created.

The formatt is in ISO8061 and includes the date and time

updated_on.description:
Date this content was last updated.

If retrieved from source version control (e.g. Git) then the value here should match the 
Git commit date for file.

The formatt is in ISO8061 and includes the date and time

organisation.description:
The name of the organisation that owns the implemened resouurce.

The owner may not be netllectual Property / Copyright owner as the
general detaisl about the resource may be in teh public domain or
this organisation has licensed the rightsto use the resource
and its secification.

name.description:
A name for the resource this document covers.

If there is a CMDB catalogue then the name here should match the
name on the CMDB.

asset.description:
Rsource information that is intended to be related to a Computer Management Database (CMDB).

By linking to the asset in an CMDB, further information can be retrieved.

If the CMDB link exists then it should be considered the authorative source where the same information exists in this definition.

If you wish the DevOps workflow to control the information and be versioned with Git, then you can use this information to push updates to the CMDB.  Just include processing of the __./well-known/devops.json__ into your deployment pipeline and post to the CMDB the updates.

owner.description:
Contact information for the resource being described.

If the resorce information is provided from a central source
such as a CMDB then this content should match.

guide.description:
A link to documentation for the resource being 
described by this document.

The preference is that the links is in the format of a HTTPS URL to a 
human readable web page.

dependency.description:
Describes the dependecies for the resource.

The dependecies include databases, downstream APIS, and build tooks.

build.description: Describes the build process, configuration and script file

test.description: Describes the test process, tools and script

health.description:
Information on the health service(s0 supported
by the resource being described in this document.

install.description:
The Install section gives information on installing the resource onto a server
for the first time.  The detection on whether the resource is already
installed is not defined in the specifications.

The information can be in the form of an Ansibe playbook or commands to 
be executed on the server.  You can also execute 
commaonds from a script file that is found on the Git repo.

refresh.description:
The Refresh section gives information on refreshing the resource on the server.  
The instructions can be the same as for installing the first time.

The information can be in the form of a Ansibe playbook or commands to 
be executed on the server with the component installed.  You can also execute 
commaonds from a script file that is found on the Git repo.

uninstall.description:
The Uninstall section gives information on uninstalling the component.

The information can be in the form of an Ansibe playbook or commands to 
be executed on the server with the component installed.  You can also execute 
commaonds from a script file that is found on the Git repo.

apis.description:
List of OpenAPI definitions.

The list can include Git and REST versions, because before build the API might not be available
as a REST service.

A resource may have multiple definitions files or even different versions.

devopsbrief-model.description:
Used only for services and not part of the 
**rediops** definition

unique_id.description: Unique identifier of he devops definitions

guide.description: Link to the guide of the devops definition

self.description:
Link to full details of rediops definition as 
defined by **deveops.json**"
